sen.j: 東福寺 （とうふくじ）は、京都市東山区本町にある臨済宗東福寺派本山の寺院。
sen.e: Tofuku-ji Temple, situated in Hommachi, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is the head temple of the Rinzai sect Tofuku-ji School of Zen Buddhism.
Tofuku-ji Temple, situated in Hommachi, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is the head temple of the Rinzai sect Tofuku-ji School of Zen Buddhism.

sen.j: 山号を慧日山（えにちさん）と号する。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Enichizan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Enichisan.

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来、開基（創立者）は、九条道家、開山（初代住職）は聖一国師円爾（しょういちこくしえんに）である。
sen.e: Its principal image is the Buddha Shakamuni, its kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Michiie KUJO and the role of kaizan (first chief priest) was fulfilled by Shoichi-kokushi Enni.

sen.j: 京都五山の第四位の禅寺として中世、近世を通じて栄えた。
sen.e: The temple had remained prestigious from middle ages right through to recent times as the fourth of the Kyoto-Gozan.
sen.cmt: ・Kyoto-Gozan: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The temple had remained prestigious from middle ages right through to recent times as the fourth Zen temple of the Kyoto-Gozan.

sen.j: 明治の廃仏毀釈で規模が縮小されたとはいえ、今なお25か寺の仏塔（たっちゅう、山内寺院）を有する大寺院である。
sen.e: Despite the fact that its former scale had been diminished during the anti-Buddhist movement of the Meiji period, even now it is an extremely large temple with 25 tatchu (sub-temples).
sen.cmt: ・the anti-Buddhist movement: EXCEED和英辞典、およびhttp://jp.wordmind.com/ecmaster-cgi/Jsearch.cgi?kwd=%A4%CF%A4%A4&word=im・tatchu (sub-temples): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm

sen.j: 境内には宋 (王朝)から伝わった「通天モミジ」と呼ばれる三葉楓（葉先が3つにわかれている）などカエデの木が多い。
sen.e: The temple precinct features a large number of maple trees including three-pointed leaf maples known as 'Tsuten Momiji' which were brought to Japan from Somg Dynsasty China.
The temple precinct features a large number of maple trees including three-pointed leaf maples known as 'Tsuten Momiji' which were brought to Japan from Sung Dynasty China.

sen.j: もとはサクラの木が植わっていたが「後世に遊興の場になる」という理由で伐採され、楓の木が植えられたものである。
sen.e: Originally, sakura cherry trees were planted but these were cut down and replaced by maple trees due to fears that the temple grounds would become merely a pleasure spot.

sen.j: また、明治時代の日露戦争の際には寺域が接収され、ロシア兵捕虜の収容施設となっていた。
sen.e: During the Russo-Japanese War of the Meiji Period, the temple precinct was confiscated and used as a detention camp for Russian prisoners of war.
sen.cmt: ・Russo-Japanese War: 英辞郎 on the WEB、プログレッシブ和英中辞典

sen.j: 歴史

History

sen.j: 東福寺は京都市東山区の東南端、伏見区と境を接するあたりにある。
sen.e: Tofuku-ji Temple is located on the southeast edge of Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City and borders Fushimi Ward.
Tofuku-ji Temple is located on the southeast edge of Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City and borders Fushimi Ward.
Tofuku-ji Temple is located on the southeast edge of Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City and borders Fushimi Ward.

sen.j: この地には延長 (元号)2年（924年）に藤原忠平によって建てられた藤原氏の氏寺・法性寺（ほっしょうじ）の巨大な伽藍があった（法性寺は、西日本旅客鉄道・京阪電気鉄道東福寺駅近くに小寺院として存続している）。
sen.e: A giant monastery belonging to the Hossho-ji Temple once stood on the site and was built as a Fujiwara clan temple in the year 924 by FUJIWARA no Tadahira (Hossho-ji Temple continues to exist as a small temple near the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) Keihan Electric Railway Tofukuji Station).
sen.cmt: ・West Japan Railway Company (JR West): http://www.westjr.co.jp/・Keihan Electric Railway : http://www.keihan.co.jp/
sen.e: A giant monastery belonging to the Hossho-ji Temple once stood on the site and was built as a Fujiwara clan temple in the year 924 by FUJIWARA no Tadahira (Hossho-ji Temple continues to exist as a small temple near the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) Keihan Electric Railway Tofukuji Station).

A giant monastery belonging to the Hossho-ji Temple once stood on the site and was built as a Fujiwara clan temple in the year 924 by FUJIWARA no Tadahira (Hossho-ji Temple continues to exist as a small temple near the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) Keihan Electric Railway Tofukuji Station).

sen.j: 嘉禎2年（1236年）、九条道家（摂政・鎌倉将軍藤原頼経の父）は、この地に高さ5丈（約15メートル）の釈迦像を安置する大寺院を建立することを発願、寺名は奈良の東大寺、興福寺の二大寺から1字ずつ取って「東福寺」とした。
sen.e: In 1236, Michiie KUJO (father of regent and Kamakura Shogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune) vowed to build a large temple housing an approximately 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni on the site and the first character of the names of each of Nara's great temples, Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple, were combined to create the name 'Tofuku-ji Temple'.

In 1236, Michiie KUJO (father of regent and Kamakura Shogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune) vowed to build a large temple housing an approximately 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni on the site and the first character of the names of each of Nara's great temples, Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple, were combined to create the name 'Tofuku-ji Temple.'

In 1236, Michiie KUJO (father of regent and Kamakura Shogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune) vowed to build a large temple housing an approximately 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni on the site and the first character of the names of each of Nara's great temples, Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple, were combined to create the name 'Tofuku-ji Temple.'

sen.j: 5丈（約15メートル）の釈迦像を安置する仏殿の建設工事は延応元年（1239年）から始めて、完成したのは建長7年（1255年）であった。
sen.e: Construction work on the butsuden (Buddha hall) housing the 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni began in 1239 and was completed in 1255.
Construction work on the Butsuden (Buddha hall) housing the 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni began in 1239 and was completed in 1255.
Construction work on the Butsuden (Buddha hall) housing the 15 meter tall statue of the Buddha Shakamuni began in 1239 and was completed in 1255.

sen.j: 高さ5丈の本尊釈迦像は元応元年（1319年）の火災で焼失、14世紀半ば頃に再興されるが、明治14年（1881年）の火災で再び焼失している。
sen.e: The statue itself was destroyed by fire in 1319 and rebuilt during the latter half of the 14th century before once again being destroyed by fire in 1881.
The statue itself was destroyed by fire in 1319 and rebuilt during the latter half of the 14th century before once again being destroyed by fire in 1881.

sen.j: なお、東福寺には巨大な「仏手」（現存部分の長さ2メートル）が保管されており、旧本尊像の左手部分のみが明治の火災の際に救い出されたものと推定されている。
sen.e: Tofuku-ji Temple is in possession of a giant Buddha's hand (the remaining 2 meters) and this is assumed to be the left hand that was saved from the Meiji period fire that destroyed the former statue of the principal image.
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB

sen.j: これは創建時の本尊ではなく、14世紀に再興された本尊像の遺物であるが、本尊の「高さ5丈」（約15メートル）というのはあながち誇張ではなかったことがわかる。
sen.e: This is a remnant of the principal image statue rebuilt in the 14th century, not that of the temples founding, but it is clear that the given height of 15 meters is no exaggeration.
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB

sen.j: 九条道家は開山（初代住職）として、当時宋での修行を終えて帰国していた禅僧・円爾（えんに、1202－1280）を迎えた。
sen.e: Michiie KUJO served as kaizan (first chief priest) and received Zen monk Enni (1202-1280) on his return to Japan from studying in Song Dynasty China.
Michiie KUJO served as kaisan (first chief priest) and received Zen monk Enni (1202-1280) on his return to Japan from studying in Song Dynasty China.
Michiie KUJO served as kaisan (first chief priest) and received Zen monk Enni (1202-1280) on his return to Japan from studying in Song Dynasty China.

sen.j: 円爾は駿河国（現在の静岡県）の人で、嘉禎元年（1235年）、宋に渡って径山（きんざん）興聖万寿禅寺の高僧・無準師範（ぶしゅんしばん、1178－1249）に入門。
sen.e: Enni was from Suruga Provenece (present day Shizuoka Prefecture) and departed for China in 1235 to study under eminent master Wuzhun Shifan (1178-124) of the Xingshen Wanshou Zen temple on Mt. Jingshan.

Enni was from Suruga Province (present day Shizuoka Prefecture) and departed for China in 1235 to study under eminent master Wuzhun Shifan (1178-1249) of the Xingshen Wanshou Zen temple on Mt. Jingshan.

Enni was from Suruga Province (present day Shizuoka Prefecture) and departed for China in 1235 to study under eminent master Wuzhun Shifan (1178-1249) of the Xingshen Wanshou Zen temple on Mt. Jingshan.

sen.j: 印可（師匠の法を受け継いだというお墨付き）を得て仁治2年（1241年）、日本へ帰国した。
sen.e: In 1241, he received inka (certification as a Zen Master) and returned to Japan.
In 1241, he received inka (certification as a Zen Master) and returned to Japan.
In 1241, he received inka (certification as a Zen Master) and returned to Japan.

sen.j: 円爾ははじめ九州博多の承天寺に住したが、同寺が天台宗徒の迫害を受けて焼き討ちされたため、九条道家の援助で上洛、東福寺の開山に迎えられた。
sen.e: Enni first resided at Joten-ji Temple in Hakata, Kyushu but this temple was persecuted by Tendai sect followers and set on fire, which led him to travel to Kyoto with the support of Michiie KUJO.
sen.cmt: ・Tendai sect: 英辞郎 on the WEB、およびhttp://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=59058&a=
sen.e: Enni first resided at Joten-ji Temple in Hakata, Kyushu but this temple was persecuted by Tendai sect followers and set on fire, which led him to travel to Kyoto with the support of Michiie KUJO, and he was received as kaisan of Tofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 東福寺の開山に迎えられた、部分が抜けている。and he was received as kaisan of Tofuku-ji Templeを補足。
sen.e: Enni first resided at Joten-ji Temple in Hakata, Kyushu but this temple was persecuted by Tendai sect followers and set on fire, which led him to travel to Kyoto with the support of Michiie KUJO, and he was received as kaisan of Tofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 東福寺の建設工事は30年以上に亘って続き、法堂（はっとう、顕教寺院の「講堂」にあたる）が完成したのは文永10年（1273年）であった。
sen.e: Construction work on Tofuku-ji Temple spanned over 30 years and its hatto (lecture hall of an exoteric Buddhist temple) was completed in 1273.
sen.cmt: ・exoteric Buddhism: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Construction work on Tofuku-ji Temple spanned over 30 years and its Hatto (lecture hall of an exoteric Buddhist temple) was completed in 1273.

sen.j: その後、元応元年（1319年）の火災をはじめたびたび焼失するが、九条家、足利家、徳川家などの援助で再建されてきた。
sen.e: Starting with the blaze of 1319, the structure was repeatedly destroyed by fire but each time was rebuilt with the support of Michiie KUJO, the Ashikaga family and the Tokugawa family among others.

Starting with the blaze of 1319, the structure was repeatedly destroyed by fire but each time was rebuilt with the support of the Kujo family, the Ashikaga family and the Tokugawa family among others.
sen.cmt: 九条家、とあるので→the Kujo family
sen.e: Starting with the blaze of 1319, the structure was repeatedly destroyed by fire but each time was rebuilt with the support of the Kujo family, the Ashikaga family and the Tokugawa family among others.

sen.j: 近代に入って1881年にも大火があり、仏殿、法堂、方丈、庫裏などがこの時焼失した。
sen.e: More recently, the great fire of 1881 destroyed structures which included the butsuden, hatto, hojo (head priest's living quarters) and Kuri (priest's living quarters or kitchen).
sen.cmt: ・hojo (head priest's living quarters): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・Kuri (priest's living quarters or kitchen): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm
sen.e: More recently, the great fire of 1881 destroyed structures which included the Butsuden, Hatto, Hojo (head priest's living quarters) and Kuri (priest's living quarters or kitchen).

sen.j: 現在の本堂、方丈、庫裏などは明治以降の再建だが、国宝の三門をはじめ、東司（便所）、浴室、禅堂などは焼け残り、中世の建物が現存している。
sen.e: The current hondo (main hall), hojo, kuri etc. were rebuilt after the Meiji period but other mediaeval structures including the sanmon gate, Tosu (lavatory) and Zendo (meditation hall) escaped the fire to remain to this day and become designated National Treasures.
sen.cmt: ・hondo (main hall): http://kyoto.asanoxn.com/places/higashiyama_sth/ryoginan/ls_ryoginan.htm・Tosu (lavatory): http://www.tofukuji.jp/index2.html・Yokushitsu (bathing room): http://www.tofukuji.jp/index2.html・Zendo (meditation hall): http://www.tofukuji.jp/index2.html・National Treasures: プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: The current Hondo (main hall), Hojo, Kuri etc. were rebuilt after the Meiji period but other mediaeval structures including the Sammon Gate, Tosu (lavatory), Yokushitsu (bathing room) and Zendo (meditation hall) escaped the fire to remain to this day and become designated National Treasures.
sen.cmt: Hondo (main hall), Hojo, Kuriに、Sammon Gate, Tosu (lavatory), Yokushitsu (bathing room) and Zendo (meditation hall)に訂正。
sen.e: The current Hondo (main hall), Hojo, Kuri etc. were rebuilt after the Meiji period but other mediaeval structures including the Sammon Gate, Tosu (lavatory), Yokushitsu (bathing room) and Zendo (meditation hall) escaped the fire to remain to this day and become designated National Treasures.

sen.j: 東福寺からは歴代多くの名僧が出ているが、中で特筆すべきは、『元亨釈書』の著者である虎関師錬（こかんしれん）と、室町時代に画僧として活躍し、その後の仏画や水墨画に多大な影響を及ぼした吉山明兆（きつざんみんちょう）であろう。
sen.e: Tofuku-ji Temple has produced a succession of many eminent monks, with the most noteworthy among these being 'Genko-Shakusho' author Kokan Shiren and the artist Kitsuzan Mincho who greatly influenced later Buddhist painting and India-ink painting.

Tofuku-ji Temple has produced a succession of many eminent monks, with the most noteworthy among these being "Genko-Shakusho" author Kokan Shiren and the artist Kitsuzan Mincho who greatly influenced later Buddhist painting and India-ink painting.

Tofuku-ji Temple has produced a succession of many eminent monks, with the most noteworthy among these being "Genko-Shakusho" author Kokan Shiren and the artist Kitsuzan Mincho who was active during Muromachi Period and greatly influenced later Buddhist painting and India-ink painting.
sen.cmt: 「室町時代に活躍し」訳抜け、補足

sen.j: 三門、仏堂、方丈、庫裏などからなる主要伽藍の北・南・西に計25か寺の塔頭寺院がある。
sen.e: The main monastery comprises of, among other structures, the sanmon gate, butsudou, hojo, and kuri, and is accompanied by a total of 25 sub-temples that are situated to its north, south and west.

sen.j: 主要伽藍の北には洗玉澗（せんぎょくかん）という渓谷があり、西から東へ臥雲橋、通天橋、偃月橋（えんげつきょう、重要文化財）という3本の橋が架かる。
sen.e: To the north of the main monastery lies a valley named Sengyokukan, which is spanned by, from west to east, the three bridges Gaun-kyo Bridge, Tsuten-kyo bridge and Engetsu-kyo bridge (Important Cultural Property).

sen.j: 通天橋は、本堂から通じる廊下がそのまま屋根付きの橋となったもので、この付近は特に紅葉の名所として知られる。
sen.e: Tsuten-kyo bridge is a continuation of the roofed hallway that leads away from the hondo and this area is particularly well-known for its Japanese maple trees.

sen.j: 橋を渡った先（北側）には、開山円爾を祀る常楽庵がある。
sen.e: On the other side of the bridge (northern side) sits Joraku-an that enshrines the temple's kaizan (first chief priest) Enni.

sen.j: －五間三戸二重門である。
sen.e: - A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances.
- A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances.
- A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances.

sen.j: 「五間三戸」とは正面の柱間が5つ、うち中央3間が通路になっているという意味、「二重門」は2階建ての門だが、「楼門」と違い、1階と2階の境目にも軒の出をつくるものを言う。
sen.e: Five bays and three entrances means that, of the five front bays, the middle three are entrances and, although it is two-storied, it is different from a romon gate in that it has an extension eave at the border between the lower and upper storeys.
sen.cmt: ・romon gate: 英辞郎 on the WEB、およびhttp://www.kamigamojinja.jp/english/index-e.html
sen.e: Five bays and three entrances means that, of the five front bays, the middle three are entrances and, although it is two-storied gate, it is different from a romon gate in that it has an extension eave at the border between the lower and upper storeys.
sen.cmt: 二重門: two-storied gateに修正。
sen.e: Five bays and three entrances means that, of the five front bays, the middle three are entrances and, although it is two-storied gate, it is different from a romon gate in that it has an extension eave at the border between the lower and upper storeys.

sen.j: 応永年間（15世紀初頭）の再建で、現存する禅寺の三門としては日本最古のものである。
sen.e: It was rebuilt at the beginning of the 15th century and is the oldest surviving Zen Buddhist temple sanmon gate in Japan.
It was rebuilt at the beginning of the 15th century and is the oldest surviving Zen Buddhist temple Sammon Gate in Japan.

sen.j: 正平 (日本)年間(1346-70)に東福寺第30世・無夢一清禅師が開いた塔頭で、びっしりと杉苔に覆われた枯山水の庭園に凛と咲くキキョウの青や白の花が美しい。
sen.e: Founded by Zen master Mumu Issei during the Shohei era (1346-1370) in Tofuku-ji Temple's 30th year; the dry landscape garden completely covered in hair moss is beautifully complemented by the blue and white of the Chinese bellflowers

sen.j: 禅宗では、弟子に師匠の肖像画を与えることは、修行が完了したことの印であり、この肖像画も円爾が師から与えられたものである。
